I must say, it doesn't mean -- it isn't -- if I can read English, to say the question is whether the notes of an interview which the witness testified had been read back to him and might have been signed by him were not in existence at the time they filed, the Court should have directed that they'll be turned over to defend for later report by the government agent which the witness testified was not a substantially verbatim account.

Now, on the context of the subject matter, there is a differentiation, just the position between notes that have been read back to him, which might have been signed by him and a document, a later document, not being a substantially verbatim account of what he had told.
I don't see why the Government doesn't start out with the first point then.
Number one, the notes originally were not producible because they were not subject to the Jencks statute.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, that is our position, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that isn't what you say anywhere.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, in our --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- in our brief, we have a counterstatement of the question involved and perhaps, I was direly tearing up beginning with that because we do not agree that a complete foundation for it is made or was made in this case.
That is where we disagree.
On page 2 of our brief, we formulate a counterstatement, namely that whether --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what I read it for --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- that's what I read it from.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: But -- but we -- we differ on this.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that means to me, the -- that -- the implication is clear that if the notes that were not in existence had been in existence, they were not challenged to be non-producible.
I must -- I must say it's very strange English.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I understood you to answer with me that the notes were in existence but the summary was the only one that was at the trial.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, no, Your Honor.
From all appearances, the notes were not in existence.
This is what the Assistant U.S. Attorney informed the court of -- below.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: He said he didn't have them but that --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes, and he doesn't say affirmatively, the Assistant doesn't, in the record that he talked to the agent but we assumed that he made some inquiry and this is what he understood to be the case.
The notes were undoubtedly destroyed because it's standard FBI procedure to do so, unless they have evidentiary value.
If the notes had -- have been signed by a person or if the notes contain information --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Well, then --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- which can be --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: -- if the notes are always destroyed, that was what my original question was aimed at then --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: -- Palermo gives us an around -- a way around the entire statute.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, no, Your Honor.
The destruction of notes is in no way calculated to --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I'm not saying in purpose.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- defeat the statute.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I mean, I don't say that's the purpose of the destruction of notes but if that is the fact, if that is the system, then the -- the statute is -- has no force in the fact.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that -- that is so only on the assumption that the notes always come within the scope of the Palermo -- of the statute.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is right, Your Honor --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Well, the summary --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- but that is --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: It's clear from Palermo that the summary never does come within.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor, but the FBI has not stopped taken written statements where it's appropriate.
Now, how they determine this hinges on -- on the -- the reality's investigative light and -- and what the agent sees at the moment.
It also hinges on whether the witness is willing to give a statement on how crucial his testimony is likely to become in an -- a number of other things.
In this case, at the time that they interviewed Staula, it was the day after the robbery and they still didn't even know who the -- the suspects were.
They were looking for general information about the robbery.

And on this point, it's important to point out that Staula, this same day after he talked to the FBI agent, was taken by the city police down to a service station where he looked at an individual and he said he couldn't positively identify that man.
He then, in the police car, was shown a number of photographs and out of these photos, he picked Lester as being the man who told him to get back against the wall in the bank.
And that is how Staula perfected his identification of Lester.
The FBI man never talked to Staula again.
This -- this is -- is, I think, a partial explanation of what happened here.
When the FBI man talked to Staula, he was interested in the general picture and we don't know what kinds of notes the FBI man took.
But whatever he took, he wrote up this interview, which is in the record, this Interview Report which is in the record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, of course, the word "notes" and the conception of notes is itself a very ambiguous term --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- from the record that has come before this Court entirely here.
There are any number of instances where the FBI takes a coherent consecutive statement and the man is trying to draw an issue of it.
I wouldn't call those notes.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, and we don't call them notes, Your Honor.
We call that a written statement.

The FBI is very careful that when it gets a statement, it is an ample one and there is very little doubt about it because it -- it always contains a prelude about the individual being advised of his rights and it ends up with who the agents were and the date of the statement.
The statement usually covers the subject involved quite -- quite amply and it's something that's almost instantly recognizable.
Now, the other kind of report, the report of an interview of a witness, runs somewhat in the form of the one that's in the record here.

And this is a very usual procedure because the agents, in the course of the day in having to interview many witnesses or here, trying to discover who did this robbery, may not have time to get a complete written statement from every person that they talked to and in this case, they apparently didn't.
They were, apparently, scores of witnesses to this robbery who testified at the trial.
Staula was just one of many.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, they're not only -- these notes often are also interluded with comment by the agent.
How (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes, indeed.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They -- they make comments that this fellow, "I don't believe him" and so on, all sorts of things.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Oh, the agent might note that the witness is nervous or any number of things like that.
This would hardly be a statement of the person and under the Jencks concept.
It would be unfair to confront the witness with this when he was called to the stand to try to impeach him with this kind of material.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, he'd hardly -- hardly show the witness that kind of notes and ask him to sign up though, would he?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, he wouldn't and I don't know of any FBI practice of a witness signing notes.
I -- I really don't, Your Honor.
They have no -- no established procedure of -- of having witnesses sign notes.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Well, that was just Staula.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do they have any --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Except where -- where a witness might draw a sketch or something like that.
They might have him sign it in that circumstance.
Excuse me, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So if Staula's recollection that he did sign this is correct, then it would follow that these things were more than just simply notes.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct.
And under established procedures, clear procedures, if he had signed those notes, they would be retained.
That is, unless the agent violated his duty here, those notes would have been retained and kept in an envelope in the case file.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, then --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- then we have a question of whether it is a statement adopted by the witness.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes, I certainly do, Your Honor because the notes may be very incomplete.
They may not be --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well -- well, my -- my reason for saying that I don't think it qualifies is that these notes could be very incomplete --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I'm talking about the summary.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: You mean the -- the inter --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- the report of interview here.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, if he had read that over and approved it --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I think that, certainly, that would come in.
It would certainly be allowable.
We have no argument on that.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, it's not the important thing if a complete statement were made up at the time of interview and approved by the witness.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What is wanted is the authentication.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But this was your witness who said that to take your -- your own view of the testimony as most favorable of the Government, that he thought it was handed to him.
He thought he read it.
He thought he signed it.
Now, that's your -- that's -- that's your witness and as I understand it, there's nothing contrary to that in the record, is there, and -- and why shouldn't you be bound by it?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
He -- he said, at one point, "I didn't sign anything.
I just -- and then there was a cross-question.
"Alright, you didn't sign it."
Then later, he thought he -- he had signed it --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
Well, but --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- and on another occasion --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- but --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- he wasn't sure.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, I know, but this is your witness.
This isn't their -- this isn't their witness.
This is your witness.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And you're bound by what your witness says.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct, but I -- I don't think --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Then why aren't you bound by the things that he says in favor of the defendant, as well as the things that are said in favor of the Government?
And if you are --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- if you are, why isn't this a statement that qualifies under Jencks?
Because he said, "I think -- I think he showed it to me.
I think I read it.
I think I signed it."
Now, if --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: And he --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- if you wanted --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- and then after that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- to disprove that that was -- wasn't the fact, why couldn't you -- that that was the fact, why couldn't you have brought the agent there to say, "Well -- well, I didn't show it to him.
He didn't sign it and I didn't read it to him."

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: For a very good reason, Your Honor.

The court pointed out to counsel in chambers when they had this one and a half hour conference about this matter that -- in fact, it was suggested by, I think, Mr. Louison, that the Government should call the agent, perhaps, to clarify this and the court said, "No, I can't allow that because the agent's testimony would be inadmissible."
You may call him and he's available and you can subpoena him or you can have the Assistant U.S. --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is that in the record?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, it's in the transcript which we have filed with the Court.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What page is that?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, the -- the trans --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, Your Honor, because we didn't know the -- the existence of this transcript until after the petition for certiorari had been granted here.
On page 10 of our brief, we refer to this transcript in a footnote.
The transcript itself or the -- the conference in chambers is referred to by the judge on page 211 of -- of this record, at the top of the page.
He speaks of a one and a half hour conference that he had wherein he listened to arguments and we had a full discussion of the briefs and where I finally decided and made a conditional decision.
Now, in this conference, I have the pages of the -- the typewritten transcript where this appears.

On pages 1831 and 1832, the judge finally decided to follow this homely procedure of -- of showing the Interview Report to the witness which he apparently had done with other witnesses in this trial to see whether he -- he agreed with this and adopted it as a statement.
And at that point, Mr. Louison said, "Your Honor, I think we should have Special Agent Toomey in here to explain where he got the document."
The Court, "No, listen.
Special Agent Toomey is a witness you have a right to subpoena and bring in here.
Obviously -- let me tell you something, now, Mr. Louison, I'm glad you spoke of that and I'm glad Mr. O'Donnell has been over it.
Obviously, no special agent, no peace officer can testify unless he can testify to something that is admissible.
And --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What -- what were they talking about?
I don't understand why -- it isn't axiomatically to me that what Toomey could have testified wasn't admissible or not.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: This is a right -- I don't know what the conflict.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Because Toomey could offer no substantive evidence in the case.
He had apparently only talked to this witness.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That's what the judge was talking about, Judge McCarthy.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That's right and secondly --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: The question of whether he could have testified to the contents of the statement --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- is an entirely different matter.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That's right and secondly, if -- if it's a question then of impeaching Staula, the Government can't bring in Toomey and put him on the stand unless it thinks that it must impeach the witness.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes, he probably could have but apparently, it didn't occur to him.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, I -- I think he could have but -- but I don't think that injects error into this case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, but I want to know what this footnote is about.
What were they talking about in chambers?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, the conference is lengthy.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I know.
What was the subject matter?
What was -- why did they adjourn to the judge's chambers?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: They adjourned because at the end of one trial day, Staula was on the stand and counsel then made their demand and the Government info -- said --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Demand for -- for what you had called us for a note.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suppose they agreed to call the non -- of the nonexistence or not available document notes and the document which is in existence a statement.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, the document which is in existence is what we call a report of interview.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright, report of interview.
Just to -- I want to differentiate the two.
What was being discussed in chambers, whether the report of interview should be -- should be produced?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I -- the discussion in chambers revolved around the original notes --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- made by the agent and also, around this question of then shouldn't this also be produced in that the notes are not available.
If they're not available, perhaps, we should be entitled to -- to this document.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, I want to know why Agent Toomey was -- why Judge McCarthy said he couldn't be called.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, he --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: As just -- Justice Brennan just indicates, he certainly could be called to testify whether the so-called notes were read and supplied to or rather signed by the petitioner, couldn't he?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No doubt about that.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- I think that Judge McCarthy indeed could have called him in camera --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So, it couldn't have been --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- and examined him.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Were they talking about that?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what he told me.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, Mr. Louison suggested that the Government call him and Judge McCarthy pointed out that the Government couldn't do that.
It would probably be reversible error because to put the agent on the stand as a government witness --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You say that he didn't sign it.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, no, but to put him on the stand and have him tell about what the witness told him at the interview may tend to support the witness.
It may give the jury --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, but -- but this is -- this is a preliminary inquiry as whether certain documents should be produced.
We're not before the jury at the moment.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: We're -- we are in the judge's chamber who's to decide whether a call for document should be heeded.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, and on that issue, I don't understand why Toomey wasn't avail -- or wasn't an admissible witness in that preliminary inquiry before Judge McCarthy.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I think he would have been but I don't think he was offered or -- or --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's -- that's -- I can't tell from this footnote what -- what it's all about.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, it was --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: He wasn't offered by the Government but counsel for the defendant insisted that he should be -- should be in there and the Government refused to -- to produce him, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I don't think the Government refused to.
I think that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- that the judge said that "You may subpoena him as a witness."
That was the language I -- I quote.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, in other words --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: You may subpoena Toomey so he --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- in other words, a -- they -- he said it's the obligation of the defense to bring him instead of the obligation of the prosecution.
Isn't that right?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- because --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- because the Government put him --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But you don't mean that, if you'd wanted to, you couldn't have brought him.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, I think he was available.
He did testify in this case --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No, no, I don't mean physically.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- at the outset.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I don't mean physically but I mean if you wanted to establish in camera before the judge on this proceeding that the -- the notes had not been shown to the witness, that he had not been asked to approve them and that he had not signed them, you could have brought the agent there, could you not, and -- and had him testify?
But you didn't want to do that.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, I don't know what the explanation for that is.
The Assistant U.S. Attorney may have felt that there was simply no need to do it here.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What -- what --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, whatever reason it was, you didn't want to do it.
Isn't that right?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, I don't know his reasons.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I didn't ask the reason.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I said you didn't want to do it.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, no, I don't think he did.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, alright.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: One would have to read, at least I would have to read, what's repeated, what -- how this conference to which footnote on this page occurs, what it was about and what it is that Judge McCarthy had in mind when he said, "You couldn't call the agent to give evidence."
Of course, you couldn't call him up to give evidence as to what, what's his name?

It's all about said but -- but what we're concerned with here is the circumstances that brought the original writings of the agent into light and secondly, what kind of things they were, whether they were within the -- the Jencks Act or not.
And assuming they were within the Jencks statute and they're not being forthcoming, whether you could then -- whether the defendant could then call for the report of the interview.
It was a very different question.
They can't be all mixed up that you could ask about it.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, I -- I think that if Your Honor reads that transcript, you will see that the court was trying to apply the statute, struggling for an interpretation of it in applying it in this case and perhaps, it didn't occur to him to call Agent Toomey in.
He felt that -- that absent a sufficient showing by the defense counsel, that there -- there was some kind of a statement that had been destroyed that -- that he need not act further.
He was satisfied when the Government told him that he didn't have the statement in its possession and -- and he indicated that -- that it was up to them to call.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, I think --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I -- I think, certainly, that would be a wise approach to take, perhaps, in -- in similar cases.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, perhaps, the judge could have acted differently than he did.
What we are urging is that this was not reversible error because the defendants were given an opportunity to call to me.
They knew his name.
I think he was available because, in reading the entire transcript of the record, I think only one-ninth of it is before you.
In reading the rest of it, I saw that Toomey appeared in the early part of the trial to identify some photographs, unless that is a different Toomey.
Perhaps, counsel can correct me if I'm wrong there.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I misconceive this whole case and I may well have misconceived it.

If I -- if it isn't a fact that it was conceded or assumed that what was originally recorded by the agent was no longer in existence, that on the basis of what is recorded, he, after, would make a report which was in existence.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And all the shooting is about -- all the shooting is about is the production of that report or striking the testimony for failure to produce it.
Isn't that what the case is about?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes, I -- I think it is, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: What --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well -- well --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) production of the summary (Inaudible)
Now, qualifying (Inaudible)
It was restricted in response to the motion that the defendants made to strike (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what I included in my statement.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And it's only secondarily that that's going to be done or they're not entirely, at least alternatively, to have been allowed to use the summary (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, I -- I think that if counsel would have conceded in answer to one question, if the summary had been made available, it certainly would have altered the -- the complexion of the case here.
Now, as I see, I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But one can assume --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- one can assume throughout that the original documentation is gone.
Isn't that -- isn't that --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- the underlying --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- assumption?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes, it's a sound inference to draw.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Very well, I understand.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: If the original notes as --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Whatever you call them.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- as they're called here.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I call them whatever.
They're gone.
There's no controversy about they having been withheld but the controversy is the consequences of their non-availability.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

And we do differ with petitioners' counsel in that we feel that no statement was ever shown to have been in existence adequately enough to lay the foundation for production here and that there was an avenue opened to them, namely calling the agent if they had any doubt about it.
They have raised the issue here and then tried to impale the Government on the horns of a dilemma, whether to call the agent or not, possibly inject reversible error into the trial.
And in this posture of the thing, we don't think the question has been, adequately enough, explored below to --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I thought you didn't read what the case was about but -- but now, you -- you destroy my belief that was clear.
You -- you suggest now that it wasn't sufficiently shown that the original document were not available.
I thought you'd agree --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, I'm sorry, Your Honor.
It's -- it's well shown that they were non-available.
I don't think it was adequately shown that these original notes or documents that were destroyed were ever the kind of thing that would be producible under -- under the statute.
I think that's where we take grave issue with the petitioners.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that, if they were not producible, if they were not compellable under the Jencks statute, certainly, and then we wouldn't be compellable.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That's -- that's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, even if --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- they weren't producible, there's no dispute -- there was no dispute at the trial about the fact that they were no longer in existence, isn't it?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct.
There is no issue as to that, as I understand it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How is that established in the record?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Your Honor, the fact that they were destroyed?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That -- yes.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, it wasn't affirmatively established in the record.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, how was it established?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, the Assistant U.S. Attorney told the court that he certainly didn't have in his possession any notes of this type and it's -- it's a common custom of the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No, let's not talk about custom.
You say it was clearly established in the record that -- that the notes were destroyed.
I asked you how and where that was clearly established.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I don't think it is established.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, then, we're -- then, you don't need to go any further.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: It is possible that the agent could have wrongfully secreted the notes but that isn't shown either and we have no reason to suspect, as one member of this Court said, that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- federal officers go around looking for opportunities to --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No, no, I wasn't saying that.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- engage in (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I was just trying to explore your statement that it was clearly established that the notes were not in existence.
That's all I want -- all I want to ask you about, where -- where it was in the record.
You say it isn't there, so that's all there is to it.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What we do have is the bottom of page 201 on the top of page 202 and that's about it, isn't it?
That's all we have.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: What's it about?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That's about all.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, Mr. Connor, we --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- plus --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- don't have any (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Excuse me, I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Have you finished?
I'm --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is there anything else besides the bottom of 201 and the top of 202 on this issue?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, except that in chambers --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What is it about?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- that this conference in chambers, something -- something occurred on this.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And that isn't testimony, that's just a colloquy between the judge and -- and the Assistant District Attorney, isn't it?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: The conference in chambers?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Who is Mr. Hurly?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Counsel for petitioner were there, too.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Who is Mr. Hurly?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Law clerk of the judge, they -- they informed me.
Mr. Hurly was --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, the judge was in a colloquy there with his law clerk and [Laughter] that's -- that's the way we make the record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Let me ask you this.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, the judge --
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How did this --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- stated on the record that the conference was to be very informal and that everyone was to feel relaxed because they were in his chambers.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: When -- when did it develop that there was in existence this report that is in existence?
How did that come up?
How did that come?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: You -- that there was an Interview Report?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: The Assistant U.S. Attorney proffered it to the court.
He said, "This is all I have."

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But where is it printed at?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Just turn to that in the record.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes, it's at the end of the -- the record.
It's at page 212.
That is the -- the report.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Page 12?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, that's --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: 212, down below.
That -- that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: 212 at the bottom.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That is the -- that is the statement but where -- where -- how did it come into the record?
I understood Justice Frankfurter asked you.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: My question is, how did the existence of that -- how did the existence of that disclosed?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, when the -- when the court called on the Assistant U.S. Attorney to produce any documents he had, he gave them this.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where is that page?
I'd like to see it in the record.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: It's -- it's here.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I think that answers the Chief Justice's question and mine.
I don't think it ever came out explicitly that the original so-called note was not available, except he clearly hasn't got them but he produces this.
And that's why I say the presupposition is the assumption of everybody was that they weren't in existence.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Your -- Your Honor, on page 201, at the bottom, the court says "Have you got in your possession any statement that was copied by an FBI agent which, in any way, would reflect a statement that this witness made?
Which would in any way," he says.
And Mr. Hobley, his clerk, says "No, Your Honor, we don't."

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, he's quite wrong.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: He is the clerk to the Assistant U.S. Attorney, isn't he?
He -- he is part of the U.S. Attorney's staff.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What?
The law clerk for the judge?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, they told me law clerk and I misunderstood them to --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He's an Assistant -- he's an Assistant US Attorney of a lower rank.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Excuse me, Hobley and Hurly are two different people.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: So --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Who's the clerk, Hobley or Hurly?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Hurly.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Hurly.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Hurly.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But -- but Mr. Connor, this must have -- something must have been said about this before that, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I think there was at an earlier time.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: "You see, Mr. Hurly," and he said he was a -- so that, it was -- if that is the transcript on page 201, Mr. Hurly, "It isn't.
It is a report for an FBI agent which is a summary of the result of the interview.
It is his interpretation of what happened."
In other words, that's the second document.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct.
This -- this is --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That would be the present controversy that's involved.
They wanted -- no, no.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They wanted this produced or the evidence stricken.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct.
They say that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now -- but -- but there must have been -- wasn't there earlier a number that it was said to the judge that "No, we can't produce that but we can produce this," wasn't there anything like that?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I think, at some point back, they were told that they had --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what I thought.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- they had a report that bore on it but they had no statement producible within the statute.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that is why I said, for me, throughout this proceeding, there was an assumption by everybody that the original documentation by Toomey was not available but they then offered this subsequent reporting, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct.

The -- the Government gave that to the court and the court looked at it and saw the nature of it and then, after this conference in chambers which went on for a long time, he went back into the courtroom and gave this to the witness to see whether he would adopt it as a state, which the witness did not do.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Then what happened?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Then, as far as the court was concerned, that concluded it, that is, the witness wouldn't adopt it, so it certainly was not producible in -- in the way that the court saw the situation and the case proceeded.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, where do you find the linking of Staula (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, I don't find anything directly on that that Staula said --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) you might need any purpose that he made or the court made, copy of the statement?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, I think they were talking about something that the FBI agent wrote down.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, what page is that?
Four.
(Inaudible)
Yes.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: He's the District Attorney.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: He is another -- he is another Assistant U.S. Attorney.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, he and Hobley were trying the case.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: He was law clerk to the judge.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, that's beforehand because the United States had possession (Inaudible) says "I do not have them in my possession.
I do not know that they ever existed."
The court, "Then you have to make Special Agent Toomey,"
(Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) find out for tomorrow morning or I could try (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes.

Well, in this transcript, I do recall that -- that the Assistant U.S. Attorney informs the judge in this hearing in chambers that he's checked with the FBI and that there are no such notes in existence.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And that's all (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That's right.
In fact, Your Honor, on page 204 where the asterisks appear near the top of the page, this is the end of the court day.
And the judge stayed up until one in the morning, he said, looking for the Holy Grail, that is, the interpretation of the Jencks Act and the next day, this conference occurred in chambers.
I believe it consumed a good part of the morning.
It was after that that the court resumed trial and that's where Dominic Staula resumed testimony, as appears on this page.
This gap is confusing otherwise but those asterisks really represent conference in chambers which is covered by that transcript which we have filed here.
And in that transcript, somewhere, as my recollection, that the Assistant U.S. Attorney said that he checked with the FBI and that there were no such notes in existence.
Now, exactly what --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did he say why they were no such note?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did he say why they were no such notes?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, I don't believe he did.
I don't believe he went into it.
The judge, in this conference in his chambers, spoke of knowing about the FBI practices and how they go about interviewing witnesses and he knew that they often took written statements --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- that were preserved and sometimes not.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- you're right about this as far as Staula (Inaudible) that he was talking about, as he said, he read back to him and he thought he signed it.
He was never thought to (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, I don't think he's very specific about it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I don't think Staula uses the term "statement".
He says that he told the agent his story and that they asked him some questions and they --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)
Certainly, he didn't talk about notes.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, I don't think he -- he talked about them writing down what he told them.
Now, that could mean terse notes or --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) notes.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I say that it's most probable that they were notes because the -- if the FBI had taken a lengthy statement, they either would have him signed this, if it were a complete statement or even if he hadn't signed it, they probably would have retained it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) that statement or do you understand the FBI man?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: There's nothing in the record done?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, nothing in the record but what I think is -- is a reasonable conclusion from the established practices.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So, what (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I -- well, for one thing, I've been in U.S. Attorney's office myself.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, and --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But you're here.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I have talked to the FBI about their practices to -- to be sure that I -- that when I came here, I didn't make a mistake in -- in putting forth the Government's position and to see that I hadn't overlooked anything.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, is it customary for the FBI, after -- after their agents have -- have interviewed a witness and they had written extensively and have shown it to the witness and the witness has adopted it as his own and signed it to thereafter destroy that document just because they made a summary?
Is that the practice --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, no, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- of the FBI?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, sir, anytime that a witness would sign a statement, it would always be retained.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But you would --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is their established procedure.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) your own witness here then by saying that he did not sign it?
He says "I think I signed it."

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: His --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's your own witness.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes, but then he said, later, he wasn't sure.
He was equivocal on this point.
And the Government --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, is there any --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- the Government can't help it if the witness' memory is poor and thinks he signed a statement when he didn't.
That is the -- the difficulty.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, but you do have the man who -- who should have a very accurate knowledge of it and you could produce him for this record if you had wanted to do it.
You could have produced the agent who -- who had said, "I just took a few desultory notes and -- and I -- I said, generally speaking, is this what you told me?
And -- and then, I went back and made a summary."
He could have said that very easily and cleared up a lot of these matters if that was the fact but you didn't choose to do that or to use him for that purpose.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, the judge asked the Assistant U.S. Attorney to check if he would and inform the court whether any such things were in existence and apparently, he did and the court felt that this was enough.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That if -- if the defense wanted to explore it further, it had avenues opened to it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But you told me, a few moments ago, if I remember it correctly, that all -- all the United States Attorney reported was that there were no such notes in existence and I ask you if he also reported that there -- that there had or had not been any at one time and then they were later destroyed, and you said there was nothing of that kind.
Now, if you were pursuing it to find out why -- why wouldn't you pursue that when you talked to your agent?
"Are there such notes in existence as far as you know?"
"No.
There are none."
"Were there any?
Did you -- did you take any?
And if so, what did you do with it?"
But that --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- that, apparently, was not brought to the attention of the Court and not made available to -- not made available to counsel, certainly.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, I think the court, in the course of this conference, showed that he -- he assumed that undoubtedly, something had been written down by the agent but he also didn't assume that there was anything improper in -- in it now being non-available.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Connor, I have started to look through this transcript.
It begins on page 1790 and as far as I've gone --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: You -- Your Honor--

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- several times, the United States representative said explicitly, "I'm requested to produce a non-existing document."
He said that two or three times, which isn't challenged or questioned or in doubt or -- or seen as the odium thrown upon it.
But I can't tell -- what precedes 1790?
I can't tell what documents they're talking about.
The judge is a notoriously defused talker.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes, and he even makes some patriotic lectures --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, I know.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- in the course of this transcript.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But I can't tell what they were talking about.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How can I -- where is the rest of the transcript?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: The -- the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What -- this begins at 1790 and this is taking place in the absence of a jury.
So, something must have happened which provokes this chamber proceeding.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes, what happened is what --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, don't you tell me, I want to know where I can get the stenographic minutes of what happened.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, it's set forth in 204 in the record where they stopped with this problem of Staula's statement and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So, what they're talking about in these -- in these stenographic minutes are what we're talking about here, is that it?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That's correct, that's what we're (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But then it's --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- in this Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- as clear as a bell that everybody assumed.
It was stated explicitly in plain unequivocal English that the documents, originally, whatever they -- their nature was, were not in existence.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Counsel can't stand by and allow such a statement made by U.S. Attorney and if they question it in their minds not to put their questions on their tongues.
So, there wasn't any doubt about it that they were not in existence.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, that's what every -- that's what they all understood to be the case then.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What was not in existence?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: The -- if -- if --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Whatever was taken down by Toomey.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It seems --seems to me like --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- if they began in 1790 and continued until 8 -- 1960 and I can't tell what it's about.
What -- what is this thing here on page 212?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Your Honor, on 212, we have the -- what we call the "Interview Report".
Now, this is what the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, is that --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- FBI agent.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- admissible in your judgment?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, not under the -- it wasn't producible under the Jencks Act.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Because it -- it wasn't a written statement.
It wasn't a statement of proof or adopted by the witness.
He has specifically rejected it at the trial when it was shown to him.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He said that he didn't give this statement?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: He said, "This isn't the way I told it to him.
It's been --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did he say it wasn't--

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- turned around."

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- did he say it wasn't the truth?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, he didn't say it wasn't true.
He said, "It isn't -- it isn't the way I told it to him."
And --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did it --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- the point--

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- did it conflict with what he had said or agree with what he had said?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No.
It -- it -- there are little ambiguities in this --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- summary by the agent --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I mean if --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- that don't accord --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- he -- this --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- to the way he testified.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- this statement says there were two individuals connected with the robbery.
How many were --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- were there according to him?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: There were three.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And this is the statement of this witness that said there were two individuals and not three?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No.
He mentions two individuals, one man in a chino pants and another man in a blue suit.
And then later on, the agent here, in reporting, says "Mr. Staula stated that he did not observe a third man in the bank."
Now, that was what the -- the dispute is partly about here.
If the agent uses this term "observe", it is ambiguous.
He could have meant that the witness saw a third man but didn't observe his physiogamy.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I don't want --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- I don't want to get his --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, no, but --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- anymore in there, but I do want to ask this question because I haven't put it at least all of them and I haven't found this out.
Non-existent, let's get back to that.
Do you mean non-existent because they did not make any statement --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- or do you mean non-existent because it has been destroyed?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: We mean non-existent in a sense that whatever it was that the agent wrote down was destroyed --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You do not mean --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- before --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- that no -- do you mean that no such statement was made as Staula testified to here where it was read back over to him?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: No, we don't contend that.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you admit that one was made at that time?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, we're -- we're saying that the agent wrote something down when he talked to Staula, that, we're sure of.
And it might just be better to say that whatever this written matter was, it was destroyed.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Has been destroyed.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Whether it's a note or a statement or whatever.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes, by then it --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: I'm --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's what you mean by non-existence?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: And maybe that gets over the semantic problem a little bit to say that whatever it was the agent wrote down, he destroyed.
Now --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Would you be willing to stand on --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- would you be willing to stand on the position taken by the Government in the brief because your brief is written without adding this additional point that you made that there never was a statement anyway?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He don't --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, no, no, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You probably misstated?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: If I misstated it, I'm sorry.
I -- I meant to say that we didn't feel that, on the record here, there's been a showing that a statement producible under the Act had ever been destroyed.
That if something was destroyed here --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I understand that, but the only thing you argue in your brief is, number one, that since the original statement, notes, whatever you want to call it, were destroyed, therefore, you couldn't be required to produce this secondary thing as a substitute because the Agent -- because Staula has repudiated the secondary notes of the agent.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That's -- that's correct, which, of course, gets back to one of the basic purposes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But now, you've been arguing, as I understand it, that apart from that, apart from that, that even though this statement had been -- the original statement had been in existence, it was a non-producible statement under the Act.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Well, we say that there's certainly no showing that -- that it was a producible statement and the avenue is to establish this were open to the defense and that they could've called the agent and found out from him what he took from --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: -- from the witness.
And that the Government would have been in a difficult position to do this, at least in open court.
Now, it's also been raised here that the judge could have done it in camera.
He didn't do it.
But that still leaves us with a problem of whether that is reversible error.
The judge here selected one method of dealing with this problem and we don't think that it was erroneous.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Two things that are clear, two things about which they ought not to be a dispute in anybody's mind when we arrive here tonight is, one, there was an original writing by Toomey which was, when asked to be produced, non-existent.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And secondly, that there was a report by the agent based on those original -- on that original writing which is concededly not within the Jencks statute.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor, and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And you -- then, the doubts that are raised is not the doubts, but you say that since the defendant was asked for the production of a document, it was incumbent upon them to come within the condition for the production laid down by the Jencks statute.
And you say further that those -- that they have not made good that requirement of them to -- to have that document produced were it in existence --

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- which is essential before they come to the next point, namely since it isn't in existence, the next best thing should be given to them or at least, if not, the evidence of the witness' about and this controversy struggles should be stricken.

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: Yes, and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's the -- that sums it all up, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: roger_g_connor
turn.label: Mr. Roger G. Connor
turn.text: That -- that essentially states our position, Your Honor.

I see I only have a few minutes and I would like to briefly talk on another point that we haven't been able to develop and that is, this question may arise that if the witness rejected this Interview Report as being his statement, was it inaccurate?
And was it so inaccurate that maybe it should have been made available?
And our answer to that is no.

In our brief, we have analyzed some of these discrepancies between the Interview Report and what Staula testified to on the stand and shown that they are not substantial and that the judge who saw this report and who heard the testimony of the witness didn't think they were substantial enough either that it should result in turning over this FBI report to the defense counsel.
For a -- one of the points was how many men were in the bank according to Staula.
He said on the stand there were three men.
He told the agent -- well, at least according to the Interview Report, he didn't observe a third man in the bank.
That could mean that there was a third man that he didn't see very well or that he didn't see anybody.
